tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This verse contains three of Allah's beautiful names: Allah, Ar-Rahman, and Ar-Raheem. 'Allah' is the greatest name of Allah, the one that encompasses all His attributes. 'Ar-Rahman' indicates that Allah's mercy encompasses all creation, while 'Ar-Raheem' indicates that Allah's mercy is specifically for the believers. The Basmalah is a means of seeking Allah's blessing and protection before beginning any action.
keyPoints: The Basmalah contains three of Allah's most beautiful names
It serves as a means of seeking blessing and protection
It should be recited before beginning any important action

tafsirSources.author: Al-Tabari
tafsirSources.commentary: The scholars have differed regarding whether the Basmalah is part of Al-Fatihah or not. However, the majority opinion is that it is part of the surah. The name 'Allah' is the proper name of the Creator, while 'Ar-Rahman' and 'Ar-Raheem' are descriptive names indicating His attribute of mercy.
keyPoints: Scholarly difference on whether Basmalah is part of Al-Fatihah
Allah is the proper name of the Creator
Ar-Rahman and Ar-Raheem describe Allah's mercy

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This verse establishes that all praise belongs to Allah alone. 'Al-Hamd' is more comprehensive than 'Ash-Shukr' (thanks) as it includes praise for both blessings and trials. 'Rabb al-Alameen' means the Lord of all creation, indicating Allah's complete ownership and control over everything in the universe.
keyPoints: All praise belongs to Allah alone
Al-Hamd is more comprehensive than thanks
Allah is the Lord of all creation

tafsirSources.author: Al-Qurtubi
tafsirSources.commentary: The word 'Al-Hamd' indicates praise that is deserved, not just any praise. It is praise that comes from recognition of Allah's perfect attributes and actions. 'Rabb' means the one who creates, owns, and manages all affairs. 'Al-Alameen' refers to all that exists besides Allah.
keyPoints: Al-Hamd is deserved praise based on recognition
Rabb means creator, owner, and manager
Al-Alameen refers to all creation

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: These two names of Allah are repeated here to emphasize His attribute of mercy. 'Ar-Rahman' indicates that Allah's mercy encompasses all creation, both believers and disbelievers, in this world. 'Ar-Raheem' indicates that Allah's mercy is specifically for the believers in the Hereafter.
keyPoints: Emphasis on Allah's attribute of mercy
Ar-Rahman: mercy for all creation in this world
Ar-Raheem: mercy specifically for believers in the Hereafter

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This verse establishes Allah's sovereignty over the Day of Judgment. 'Malik' means the owner and ruler who has complete authority. 'Yawm ad-Deen' refers to the Day of Judgment when all people will be recompensed for their deeds. This verse reminds us that Allah alone has the authority to judge and reward or punish.
keyPoints: Allah is the owner and ruler of the Day of Judgment
Complete authority belongs to Allah alone
Reminder of accountability and divine justice

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This verse establishes the proper relationship between the servant and Allah. 'Iyyaka na'budu' means we worship You alone, and 'Iyyaka nasta'een' means we seek help from You alone. The repetition of 'Iyyaka' emphasizes exclusivity - we worship none but Allah and seek help from none but Allah.
keyPoints: Exclusive worship of Allah alone
Exclusive reliance on Allah for help
Proper relationship between servant and Lord

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This is a supplication for guidance to the straight path. 'As-Sirat al-Mustaqeem' refers to the clear path that leads to Allah and Paradise. It is the path of Islam, the path of the Prophet Muhammad and his companions. This supplication should be made continuously as guidance is needed at every step.
keyPoints: Supplication for continuous guidance
As-Sirat al-Mustaqeem is the path of Islam
Guidance is needed at every step of life

tafsir.arabicText: صِرَاطَ الَّذِينَ أَنْعَمْتَ عَلَيْهِمْ غَيْرِ الْمَغْضُوبِ عَلَيْهِمْ وَلَا الضَّالِّينَ

tafsirSources.author: Ibn Kathir
tafsirSources.commentary: This verse clarifies what the straight path is. It is the path of those whom Allah has blessed - the prophets, the truthful, the martyrs, and the righteous. We should avoid the path of those who have earned Allah's anger (the Jews who knew the truth but rejected it) and those who have gone astray (the Christians who followed innovations).
keyPoints: The straight path is that of the blessed ones
Avoid the path of those who earned Allah's anger
Avoid the path of those who went astray

overallCommentary.significance: Al-Fatihah is the greatest surah in the Quran and is essential in every prayer. It contains the fundamental principles of Islam: belief in Allah's oneness, His attributes, His sovereignty, the proper relationship between servant and Lord, and the supplication for guidance.
practicalApplication: Use as a supplication in daily life
Reflect on the meanings during prayer
Apply the guidance in daily decisions
